awd_titl_txt: Operation of the HAWC Gamma Ray Observatory
awd_abstract_narration:
Gamma-rays are the highest energy form of electromagnetic radiation. Observations of astrophysical gamma-rays serve as probes of physical conditions and processes in the most extreme environments throughout the Universe and can be used to test fundamental physics. The High Altitude Water Cherenkov (HAWC) observatory, located on the slopes of the Sierra Negra in Mexico, is a ground-based facility designed with unique capabilities to observe very high energy gamma-rays.  With its large instantaneous field of view and continuous operations HAWC surveys two-thirds of the sky every day.  HAWC observations have provided new views of the high energy sky and led to the discovery of new sources.  This award to the University of Maryland College Park supports the continued operation of HAWC.  This award will also support HAWC's public outreach programs that include outreach to the Hispanic-American community with bi-lingual products related to HAWC. 

HAWC will continue to perform deep surveys of the gamma-ray sky and will observe a large sample of gamma-ray sources with measurements of flux, spectra and variability. HAWC's wide field and high sensitivity enable studies of extended sources and diffuse emission from the Galactic plane.  HAWC plays an important role in multi-wavelength and multi-messenger astrophysics campaigns.  The University of Maryland plays a critical role in HAWC operations.  The PI serves as U.S. Spokesperson for HAWC and the Co-PI serves as HAWC Data Manager.  With this award they will continue to operate and maintain the HAWC observatory, maintain the US data archive, and provide public data access to sky maps and real-time transient alerts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The High-Altitude Water Cherenkov (HAWC) Gamma-Ray Observatory has revolutionized high-energy astrophysics, providing new insights into cosmic ray origins, particle acceleration, and transient phenomena. As one of the most sensitive wide-field telescopes for TeV gamma rays, HAWC continuously monitors the Northern sky and has made groundbreaking contributions to our understanding of the universe.

Intellectual Merit 

Probing Extreme Cosmic Phenomena 

HAWC studies the origins of cosmic rays and the processes that accelerate particles to extreme energies. Its observations have revealed critical insights into astrophysical environments like supernova remnants, pulsar wind nebulae, and black holes. Key discoveries include TeV halos, regions around pulsars where high-energy particles interact with matter, offering new perspectives on cosmic ray propagation.

HAWC has also identified Galactic PeVatrons, including the detection of gamma rays above 100 TeV from the Galactic Center, indicating extreme particle acceleration near the Milky Way’s supermassive black hole.

Expanding the Gamma-Ray Source Catalog 

Over nearly a decade, HAWC has discovered more than 40 new gamma-ray sources, including microquasars like SS433 and V4641. These findings enrich the global catalog of high-energy astrophysical objects, supporting research across the scientific community.

Advancing Techniques and Exploring New Physics 

HAWC’s innovative analysis methods enable the extraction of detailed information from faint gamma-ray signals. Its sensitivity to TeV–PeV gamma rays has positioned it to search for phenomena beyond the Standard Model, such as gamma-ray counterparts to gravitational waves or neutrino events.

 Broader Impacts 

Expanding Diversity in STEM 

 HAWC is one of the most prominent science projects in Mexico, and we have leveraged this visibility to promote greater diversity in STEM fields. Our active public outreach program, conducted in both English and Spanish, targets educational institutions ranging from elementary schools to universities in the U.S. and Mexico. We have engaged students at all levels—from high school to graduate programs—in the construction, analysis, and operation of the HAWC detector. Through these efforts, we aim to inspire underrepresented groups to pursue studies and careers in STEM, fostering inclusivity and broadening participation in the field.

Unparalleled Observational Capabilities 

 As the only wide-field TeV gamma-ray observatory in the Western Hemisphere, HAWC plays a critical role in detecting transient phenomena like gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), active galactic nucleus (AGN) flares, and gravitational-wave-related emissions. It issues prompt alerts for flaring AGN, enabling rapid follow-up observations by other observatories.

 Collaboration Across Observatories 

 HAWC works closely with Imaging Atmospheric Cherenkov Telescopes (IACTs), providing source discoveries for follow-up studies and enabling joint analyses over a wide energy range. These partnerships have enriched datasets and deepened our understanding of high-energy astrophysical processes.

 Education and Training 

 HAWC is a valuable training platform for students and postdoctoral researchers. Participants gain hands-on experience in hardware, data analysis, and scientific collaboration. On-site work helps students develop practical skills and a comprehensive understanding of high-energy astrophysics.

 Public Engagement 

 HAWC’s discoveries highlight the universe’s most extreme and mysterious phenomena, inspiring the public and fostering interest in science. Outreach activities include public lectures, educational resources, and collaborations with science communicators to share HAWC’s findings widely.

 Preparing for the Future 

 HAWC’s success paves the way for next-generation observatories like the Southern Wide-field Gamma-ray Observatory (SWGO). By transferring technology and expertise, HAWC ensures future facilities will continue exploring profound astrophysical questions.

 Conclusion 

 HAWC has transformed our understanding of the high-energy universe, from uncovering the origins of cosmic rays to detecting transient phenomena. Its unique observational capabilities and collaborative efforts have positioned it as a cornerstone of modern astrophysics. By fostering education and inspiring future scientists, HAWC leaves a lasting legacy of discovery and innovation, advancing both the intellectual merit and broader impacts of astrophysical research.
